SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Fatigue, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian Smith is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He has been involved in home renovations and has had difficulty maintaining a healthy diet due to eating out frequently. He has experienced some bloating and shortness of breath when exerting energy. He has a slight cough and occasional chest cramps that resolve after about an hour.

Regarding his congestive heart failure, he has been compliant with medications and has been monitoring his blood pressure regularly at home.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or weight loss. Endorses fatigue and lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses shortness of breath and occasional chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Endorses a slight cough.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm. Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in the lower extremities.

Results:

Chest x-ray shows some fluid in the lungs.

Echocardiogram from four months ago shows a reduced ejection fraction of 45% and mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Brian Smith is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems.

Congestive heart failure.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is experiencing fluid retention, as evidenced by the physical exam findings and chest x-ray.
• Additional Testing: Order another echocardiogram.
• Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once daily. Instruct the patient to weigh himself daily and call if there is significant weight gain or worsening shortness of breath.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure appears to be well-managed at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg once daily. Instruct the patient to continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevated readings through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up after test results are received.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today with right knee pain after a fall. She reports that she was on a ladder changing a light bulb when she stumbled and twisted her knee while trying to catch her fall. The incident occurred yesterday. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it has not provided significant relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Atrial fibrillation.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY

Rhinoplasty.

MEDICATIONS

Digoxin.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Knee: Tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain with valgus stress.
• Sensation: Normal sensation in the lower extremity.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the left knee shows no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents with right knee pain after a fall. Based on the physical examination and x-ray findings, the most likely diagnosis is an acute medial meniscus sprain or strain.

• Medical Treatment: We will prescribe Motrin 800 mg every six hours with food for two weeks.
• Orthopedic Management: We will provide a knee brace and crutches for temporary use. The patient will return for a follow-up visit in one week. If there is no improvement, we will consider ordering an MRI at that time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan Smith is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with lower back pain. The patient reports lifting heavy boxes on Saturday and experiencing a popping sensation in his lower back, followed by pain and stiffness. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and Icy Hot for pain relief with minimal improvement. He also reports tingling in his right toes, which resolved by Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, the patient admits to not having a great diet recently due to helping his daughter and being on the go. He has been taking his medications for hypertension and monitoring his blood pressure at home during the week.

The patient denies chest pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and chills.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back pain and early arthritis in the knee.
• Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling in legs, except for resolved tingling in right toes.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable from previous exams.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension of the back, negative straight leg raise.

RESULTS

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

Normal back x-ray with good bony alignment and no fracture present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan Smith is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. He presents today with lower back pain.

Lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's history of lifting heavy boxes and experiencing a popping sensation in the lower back is consistent with a lumbar strain.
• Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity, and refer to physical therapy.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8, indicating suboptimal control of diabetes.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily, repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure readings are running on the high side.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee osteoarthritis well and does not require further workup at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam, depression, and hypertension.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph Johnson is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension, who presents for his annual exam. The patient reports managing his depression well with Prozac and has not had any incidents recently. He has been struggling with hypertension, taking Norvasc regularly during the business week but occasionally forgetting on weekends. He experienced some nasal congestion due to pollen and shortness of breath with exertion while running.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain. Endorses shortness of breath with exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies cough. Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies muscle aches.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. No extra heart sounds.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema. Pain to palpation of sinuses.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.

Chest X-ray: Unremarkable, normal post-lobectomy appearance.

Blood pressure: 120/80, improved from prior trends.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ralph Johnson is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension, who presents for his annual exam.

1. Depression: Well-managed with Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication. Refill Prozac 20 mg daily.

2. Prior lobectomy: No further workup needed, as the patient is exercising regularly and has good breathing function.

3. Hypertension: Blood pressure is well-controlled with Norvasc.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.

4. Nasal congestion: Likely due to pollen.
   • Patient Education: Monitor symptoms and consider over-the-counter allergy medications if needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents for right finger pain. The patient was skiing over the weekend and experienced an injury to her right finger while going over moguls. The injury occurred four days ago. She has tried ice and ibuprofen for pain management but reports that the pain persists. The patient also mentions a recent history of constipation, for which she takes Miralax. She has a past surgical history of an appendectomy at age 18.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Right Finger:
• Tenderness over the distal phalanx and the joint itself
• No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint
• Pain with flexion

X-RAY RESULTS

The x-ray of the right hand shows no fractures and everything lines up well.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 48-year-old female presenting with right finger pain after a skiing injury. Based on the physical examination and x-ray results, the diagnosis is a right hand index finger contusion on the tip of the finger.

Treatment Plan:
1. Aluminum foam splint for the right index finger
2. Motrin 600 mg every six hours for one week

The patient is advised to call and return for a follow-up if the pain does not improve within a week.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female who has been dealing with iron deficiency anemia since she was 13 years old. She recently tried to donate blood in December and was told she was anemic. She has been feeling fatigued, feverish with chills, short of breath, and experiencing headaches. She also reports increased sensitivity to cold and worsening anxiety and depression.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hysterectomy in 1996.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• General: Fatigue, feverish with chills.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath, wheezing.
• Neurological: Headaches.
• Psychiatric: Anxiety and depression.

MEDICATIONS

Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily.
Over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
• Gastrointestinal: Abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a history of iron deficiency anemia.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: She has been dealing with anemia since she was 13 years old and has recently been experiencing fatigue, shortness of breath, and headaches.
• Additional Testing: Schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
• Medical Treatment: Continue taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily with orange juice for better absorption. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 8-12 weeks.
• Referral: Refer to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.

Anxiety and depression.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports worsening anxiety and depression.
• Medical Treatment: Monitor and consider referral to a mental health professional if symptoms persist or worsen.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

High blood sugar.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 58-year-old male who presents for evaluation of high blood sugar.

The patient states he has been taking his blood sugars at home, and they have been in the 300's. He notes that his diet has not changed much. He does not eat processed food, nor does he put sugar in his tea. The patient reports that he thinks the sugar in his diet is from fruit. He denies any fever, chills, or body aches. He endorses joint pain in his right knee; however, he notes that he just noticed the joint pain when asked. He states he was nauseous for a couple of days but that was because he was sitting in the back of a car. He denies any burning with urination.

The patient has a history of congestive heart failure. He denies any recent weight gain or fluid retention. He has no problems laying flat.

The patient has a history of right rotator cuff issues which he notes are doing well.

He notes that his reflux is doing better. The patient reports that he no longer gets up at night from reflux.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Negative for fever, chills or unintentional weight changes.
• Musculoskeletal: Positive for right knee pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Neck
• General Examination: Neck is supple, mild thyromegaly noted.

Respiratory
• Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
• Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm.

Gastrointestinal
• Examination of Abdomen: Soft.

Musculoskeletal
• Examination: Right knee shows some erythema and insect bite with associated fluctuance. Trace edema in the right lower extremity.

RESULTS

Lyme titer: elevated.

Rapid strep test: positive.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 58-year-old male who presents for evaluation of high blood sugar.

Hyperglycemia
• Medical Reasoning: This is likely related to an inflammatory response as the patient had an elevated Lyme titer and positive rapid strep test.
• Additional Testing: We will order a western blot PCR to evaluate for Lyme disease.
• Medical Treatment: We are going to treat him with amoxicillin 500 mg 3 times a day for 10 days.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Hill is a 53-year-old female who presents with a history of chest pain that occurred three months ago. The pain was located in the center of her chest, right behind her breastbone, and was sharp in nature. The pain lasted for four days and was associated with difficulty swallowing. She went to the ER, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, which were normal. The patient has not had any chest pain since that time. She reports that she was going through a stressful job transition around the time of the chest pain.

Ms. Hill has a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fevers, chills. Positive fatigue.
• Cardiovascular: Chest pain resolved since the initial episode three months ago.
• Respiratory: No shortness of breath or wheezing.
• Gastrointestinal: No abdominal pain. Normal bowel movements. Difficulty swallowing resolved since the initial episode.
• Musculoskeletal: No joint pain or muscle aches.
• Neurological: No dizziness or lightheadedness.
• Psychiatric: Possible anxiety related to job transition.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: In no apparent distress.
• Neck: Supple without thyromegaly or lymphadenopathy.
• Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm.
• Gastrointestinal: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No rebound or guarding.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female who presents with a history of chest pain and difficulty swallowing that occurred three months ago and resolved after four days.

Possible etiologies:
• GERD
• Dyspepsia
• Esophagitis
• Musculoskeletal etiologies
• Anxiety

Suspect she had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, plus or minus a contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies.

Plan:
• Discussed the option of EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change.
• Follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy. The patient has also seen an orthopedic specialist and an ophthalmologist. The patient's geneticist mentioned the possibility of kidney anomalies associated with the syndrome, prompting the visit for evaluation.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Gastrointestinal: Positive for reflux.
• Musculoskeletal: Positive for developmental delays.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General Examination: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of kidney function. Given the potential for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract associated with the syndrome, a kidney ultrasound will be performed. If the ultrasound shows abnormalities, further steps and follow-up will be determined. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so future follow-up should be at the town center location.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a patient who presents with a right wrist injury after slipping on stairs while doing laundry. She reports severe pain (9/10) and swelling in the wrist. The injury occurred yesterday morning. She has tried ice, an ace wrap, and ibuprofen for pain relief, but the pain persists. She denies any previous injuries to the arm. She reports some tingling in her fingers but no pain extension elsewhere.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Head and Neck
• General Examination: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.

Cardiovascular
• Auscultation of Heart: No murmur, rub, or gallop.

Respiratory
• Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Extremities
• Upper Extremities: Normal range of movement in the left wrist. Right wrist shows pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Able to make a fist but not tightly. Obvious swelling and bruising in the right wrist. Tenderness on palpation and evidence of potential fracture with bony crepitus.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 140/70 mmHg (elevated)
Heart rate: 80 bpm (elevated)
Temperature: 97.2°F
Respiratory rate: 20

RESULTS

X-ray: Positive for Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Diana presents with a right wrist injury after a fall. Physical examination and X-ray confirm a Colles' fracture. The plan is to provide conservative treatment initially with a brace and pain management using 50 mg of Ultram every six hours. Surgery is recommended, followed by physical therapy three times a week for six weeks. A follow-up appointment in a month will assess her progress and determine if she can proceed with her planned vacation.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Philip is a patient with a past medical history of hypertension who presents with right knee pain. The patient reports that he slipped and fell while working on his property a week ago. He felt something pop in his knee and has been experiencing pain and swelling since the incident. The pain is worse with flexion and extension of the knee. He has been taking ibuprofen for the swelling.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: Right knee with pain to palpation of the medial aspect, pain with flexion and extension, edema, and effusion.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 150/70, elevated.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the right knee: No fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee pain - MCL strain.
   • Medical Treatment: Ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling.
   • Supportive Care: Knee brace, ice therapy (20 minutes, 3-4 times a day), and elevation of the leg.
   
2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Referral to nutrition for dietary management and sodium reduction.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Wayne is a middle-aged male who presents with left shoulder pain for the past three weeks. He does not recall any specific injury but has been active and doing a lot of work in his basement. He has had occasional aches and pains in the past but nothing that Tylenol couldn't take care of. The pain is always present and worsens when he tries to put pressure on it or reach for something overhead. He has been taking two extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours, which takes the edge off but does not completely alleviate the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his arms or hands.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Positive for left shoulder pain and limited range of motion. No numbness or tingling in arms or hands.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vitals: Reviewed and within normal limits.
• Left Shoulder: Limited active and passive range of motion, tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus, no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints.
• Neurovascular: Capillary refill less than three seconds, sensation intact to light touch.

RESULTS

X-ray of the left shoulder: No fractures.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Mr. Wayne presents with left shoulder pain, most likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy. An MRI of the left shoulder will be ordered to further evaluate the issue. He will be referred to physical therapy for approximately six to eight weeks and may continue to take Tylenol for pain management. If symptoms do not improve, a steroid injection for the shoulder may be considered. The patient will follow up after completing physical therapy.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a patient who presents with occasional left knee pain and instability. She reports that her knee "gives out" less than once a day while walking, causing her to feel like she might fall. She has not experienced any popping or prior injuries to the knee. The pain is internal and involves the whole kneecap. The episodes of instability are brief and resolve quickly. Andrea has not taken any pain medications for this issue, as the pain does not last long. She is concerned about participating in line dancing during an upcoming trip due to her knee instability.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Andrea has a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus. She is currently taking lisinopril, amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, and metformin.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2°F, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.

Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Left Knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left Knee X-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. Left knee pain and instability:
   - Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily.
   - Consider physical therapy to strengthen muscles around the knee and prevent further problems.

2. Hypertension:
   - Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.
   - Order echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur.

3. Diabetes mellitus:
   - Order hemoglobin A1c to assess the need for adjustments to metformin.
   - Order lipid panel.

INSTRUCTIONS

Schedule a follow-up appointment to discuss test results and evaluate the effectiveness of the meloxicam for knee pain.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer, cough, and sore throat.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She presents for follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, and biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending at this time. The patient reports a minimal cough and a sore throat. She experiences fatigue but denies nausea or vomiting. She has a dry cough and no shortness of breath. The patient has a persistent sore throat that comes and goes.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Respiratory: Positive for dry cough and sore throat.
• Gastrointestinal: Negative for difficulty swallowing or feeling of food getting stuck.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Neck
• General Examination: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy noted.

Cardiovascular
• Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs appreciated.

Respiratory
• Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
• Examination: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side, likely related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
• Examination: No edema noted.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer
   • Medical Treatment: Continue with the current regimen of chemotherapy (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of treatment to evaluate for potential surgical removal of the tumor.

2. Radiation pneumonitis
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to help reduce inflammation.

3. Painful swallowing
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to help with pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Kyle is a patient who was referred by his primary care physician due to a low immunoglobulin A level found during a recent physical examination. The patient reports a history of frequent colds during the winter months, which tend to linger for a long time. He denies any recent abdominal infections or diarrhea. He has a family history of type 2 diabetes and was recently started on metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever, weight loss, or significant weight gain.
• Respiratory: Endorses frequent colds during winter months.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal infections or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Within normal limits, no fever.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs appreciated.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
• Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, no organomegaly.

LABORATORY RESULTS

IgA level: Low (consistent with IgA deficiency)

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. IgA deficiency:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient has a low IgA level, which is a common immunodeficiency. He reports a history of frequent colds but does not seem to have significant recurrent infections.
   • Additional Testing: Order blood work to check for other immunodeficiencies.
   • Patient Education: Instruct the patient to inform healthcare providers of his IgA deficiency if he requires blood products in the future.

2. Type 2 diabetes:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient has a family history of diabetes and was recently started on metformin.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue metformin as prescribed by the primary care physician.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up after the additional blood work is completed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a patient who presents today for evaluation and management of right elbow pain. The patient reports that the pain started about four days ago and has been persistent since then. He has been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. The pain is located on the inside of his right elbow and sometimes radiates down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The pain is rated as a 6/10 and has been affecting his sleep and daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

PAST HISTORY

No significant past medical history.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ibuprofen as needed for pain.

ALLERGIES

No known allergies.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.

Focused exam of the right elbow:
- Positive for pain to palpation at the medial epicondyle.
- Positive for pain with pronation of the forearm.
- Positive for pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

X-ray of the right elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality detected.

ASSESSMENT

Medial epicondylitis (right elbow pain).

PLAN

1. Rest: The patient is advised to rest the affected elbow and avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
2. Sling: The patient will be provided with a sling to wear while awake.
3. Ice: Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
4. Medication: Ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for one week.
5. Follow-up: The patient will return for a follow-up appointment in one week to assess progress.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is instructed to follow the above plan and return for a follow-up appointment in one week. If the pain worsens or new symptoms develop, the patient should contact the clinic immediately.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Hypertension and recent fall.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

David is a middle-aged male who presents today for a follow-up evaluation after a recent visit to the emergency department due to a fall. He reports experiencing chest pain and shortness of breath prior to the fall but did not think much of it. He has a history of hypertension and has been taking Bumex, Cozaar, and Norvasc, although he admits to occasionally missing doses.

The patient reports swelling in his ankles and shortness of breath. He has not been monitoring his diet closely and has been consuming salty foods such as chips. He has not experienced any significant weight loss or gain, headaches, bone pain, urinary symptoms, or blood in the stools. He denies any recent issues with sleep and believes his chest pain may be due to heartburn.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Hypertension.

Surgical
None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Alcohol: None reported.
Illicit drug use: None reported.
Tobacco: Former smoker, quit a couple of years ago, occasional use (once a week).

FAMILY HISTORY

Not reported.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Bumex 2 mg daily.
Cozaar 100 mg daily.
Norvasc 5 mg daily.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for weight loss, weight gain, headaches, bone pain, urinary symptoms, blood in the stools.
Positive for chest pain, shortness of breath, and ankle swelling.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Blood pressure: 128/72.
Neck: No jugular venous distention.
Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
Lungs: Clear bilaterally.
Lower extremities: Trace edema.

ASSESSMENT

1. Hypertension, uncontrolled.
2. Recent fall with chest pain and shortness of breath.

PLAN

1. Continue Bumex 2 mg daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg daily. Encourage patient to take medications consistently.
2. Consult with nutritionist to address dietary concerns and reduce salt intake.
3. Obtain a home blood pressure cuff and monitor blood pressure regularly.
4. Obtain a home scale and monitor weight daily. Call if weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days.
5. Order renal artery ultrasound to rule out any underlying issues.
6. Follow up in 1 month or sooner if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain and history of kidney stones.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe, making it difficult for him to find a comfortable position. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain with minimal relief. The patient has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones in his father.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for fever, chills, and vomiting. Positive for nausea.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Previous kidney stones.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS
Imaging

CT scan of the abdomen: 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain. Continue Tylenol as needed.
3. Provide a urine strainer for the patient to collect the stone when it passes.
4. Order basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Follow up in 1-2 weeks to reevaluate symptoms and discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy if necessary.
6. Instruct the patient to contact the clinic if symptoms worsen or new symptoms develop.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow up in 1-2 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents with a non-healing foot ulcer on his right foot. He first noticed the ulcer approximately six weeks ago after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The patient initially experienced stinging and burning sensations, which progressed to a foul smell, yellow drainage, and the blister becoming unroofed. He has been on antibiotics for six days, and his wife reported a fever of 99.7°F and chills. The patient has noticed the wound turning black around the edges and has experienced cramping in his calf muscle. He also reports a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is hot to touch. The patient has been coughing and experiencing shortness of breath.

The patient's blood sugars have been trending in the 300-400 range over the past two weeks, with one spike at 500-600. His A1C is 6.7.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Fever of 99.7°F, chills.
• Respiratory: Coughing, shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Cramping in calf muscle.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
• Foot Exam: Necrotic wound on the right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythema, foul odor, no bony exposure.
• Vascular Exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses, non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses (present via Doppler).

RESULTS

Right foot x-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Nicholas presents with a non-healing diabetic foot ulcer on his right foot.

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer:
   • Medical Reasoning: Necrotic wound with cellulitis and erythema, no bony exposure, and no evidence of osteomyelitis on x-ray.
   • Additional Testing: Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
   • Medical Treatment: Perform debridement in the office, culture the wound, and consider different antibiotic therapy based on culture results.
   • Follow-up: Monitor the redness and swelling in the calf, and schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.

2. Diabetes management:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood sugars trending high and A1C of 6.7.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current diabetes management.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist and maintain an A1C below 7.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Richard is a pleasant patient who presents today with a tick bite on his right knee. He is unsure of when he got the tick bite but reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and working in his yard. The tick bite has been present for over a week and is causing burning and discomfort. He denies any fever or chills but reports feeling generally unwell and experiencing headaches since the tick bite.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Hypertension.
Diabetes.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Employed.
Enjoys hunting and spending time outdoors.

ALLERGIES

No known drug allergies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• General: Feeling unwell and experiencing headaches since tick bite.
• Musculoskeletal: Right knee pain and discomfort.
• Endocrine: Diabetes.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Constitutional
Pleasant, cooperative male in no apparent distress.

Cardiovascular
Regular rate and rhythm.

Musculoskeletal
Right knee with erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee.

Skin
Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT

• Possible Lyme disease due to tick bite and bull's-eye rash on right knee.
• Hypertension.
• Diabetes.

PLAN

1. For tick bite and possible Lyme disease:
   - Start doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for 3 weeks.
   - Order Lyme titer and Western blot tests.
   - Monitor for any worsening symptoms or involvement of other organs.

2. For hypertension:
   - Continue lisinopril 20 mg once a day.
   - Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. For diabetes:
   - Continue metformin 1000 mg twice a day.
   - Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control.
   - Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

The patient understands the treatment plan and agrees to follow up as needed. All questions were answered to the patient's satisfaction.
